snippet: Questions have only increased since a Lewis-McChord soldier was accused of killing at least 16 Afghan civilians, including 9 children, in an assassination-style ambush.
abstract: Massacre of 16 Afghan civilians by a soldier from the Lewis-McChord army base in Washington State has increased scrutiny on the installation; base has a controversial record of handling mental health issues, along with high rates of suicide, domestic violence and homicides committed by its soldiers; data suggests that trend, including a large number of reversed diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder, has also surfaced at other major bases.

byline.original: By WILLIAM YARDLEY, SERGE F. KOVALESKI and JAMES DAO
byline.contributor: William Yardley and Serge F. Kovaleski reported from Joint Base Lewis-McChord, and James Dao from New York.
